titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Special Collections Research Center oral history collection, 1972-2016 MS0371
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 14:15:20 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Special Collections Research Center oral history collection

physdesc.extent: 11 document boxes, 1 slim document box, 7 cassette tape boxes, 9 record center cartons, and digital objects.

did.abstract: The George Washington University Oral History Program was begun by Mary Jo Deering and others in the early 1970s. Since that time, oral histories have been conducted by a number of individuals and projects represented in this collection. This collection consists primarily of oral histories conducted by or about George Washington University, although it also contains administrative files related to the oral history programs, and a significant amount of documentary material on school desegregation and the Rosemary Hills controversy.
did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site, and may require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Whenever it is known, acquisition data is included at the series or item level.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The George Washington University Oral History Program was begun by Mary Jo Deering and others in the early 1970s. Situated in the university library, this program appears to have had both teaching and collecting aims, as it engaged in large documentation projects on current local issues, and also taught participants how to conduct and transcribe oral histories. In 1976, Deering and Barbara Pomeroy published a booklet titled "Transcribing Without Tears: A Guide to Transcribing and Editing Oral History Interviews."

The largest, and possibly the first, project of the Oral History Program was to document ongoing and recent events around the desegregation of schools in Montgomery County, Maryland. This project was conceived broadly, and included the collection of a significant body of small publications and clippings related to desegregation both locally and nationally. Around this same time, the program also conducted a series of 18 interviews with University Historian Elmer Louis Keyser on a range of topics related to GW history.
This first GW Oral History Program program ended in the early 1980s, having failed to secure grant funding for additional projects, including one on DC's Wolf Trap Theater.

Contemporaneously with this oral history program, a Medical Center Oral History Committee was formed which identified, supervised, and collected oral histories from faculty, staff, and alumni of the George Washington University Medical Center. This program also ended by the mid 1980s.

In 1988, with the creation of a formal University Archives, University Archivist G. David Anderson began to conduct additional oral histories with the goal "To broaden and enrich the archival record of the University, supplementing the written recordâ€¦. by recording on tape the recollections, impressions, attitudes and feelings of those associated with The George Washington University."

Other oral history special projects have included interviews with Foggy Bottom residents to coincide with the 200th anniversary of GW's presence in the neighborhood, and lengthy series of interviews with retiring GW Presidents Lloyd H. Elliot and Stephen J. Trachtenberg.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains consists primarily of oral histories conducted by or about George Washington University. The interviews exist in a variety of formats, including reel-to-reel tapes, audio cassette tapes, printed transcripts, digital files of transcripts, and digital recordings. Subjects covered by the interviews other than GW history include a school desegregation controversy in Montgomery County, Maryland in the 1970s; life experiences of long-term Foggy Bottom neighborhood residents; Washington, D.C. performing arts; and fair housing campaigns. The collection also includes interviews with Walter Fauntroy and Ari and Phyllis Kiev.

In addition to the interviews and transcripts, the collection includes administrative records related to the conduct of the interviews (correspondence, notes, etc.) as well as administrative records related to the various oral history projects represented in the collection.

Finally, the collection includes a significant amount of documentary material on school desegregation and the Rosemary Hills controversy, such as pamphlets, flyers, small publications, and newspaper clippings, that were intended to support the use of the related oral histories as a teaching collection. A detailed inventory of these items is located in Box 16.

This collection also includes oral histories conducted by undergraduate GW students Spring 2013 course HIST2020W, "Washington, DC: History, Culture, and Politics," taught by Dr. Christopher Klemek. These interviews are with former and current residents of Foggy Bottom and Southwest and discuss the 20th century history of the neighborhoods.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: Rosemary Hills school integration oral history and documentation project, George Washington University oral histories, Medical Center Oral History Committee, Foggy Bottom oral histories, and Miscellaneous oral histories and administrative files.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Some interviews in this collection are closed due to a lack of a signed release from the interviewee. A very small number of additional interviews have signed releases with further restrictions. These restricted and closed interviews are noted at the item level in the finding aid.

Physical files and transcripts of closed interviews have been moved to red boxes with an "R" number, although the cassette and reel-to-reel recordings of the interviews remain interfiled with open interviews.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was significantly re-organized in 2017. At that time, series structure and numbers, as well as most box numbers were changed, as the collection was organized for the first time by project and interview, rather than physical carrier. Non-oral history materials, particularly recordings of GW-related events, were removed from the collection, as were duplicate transcriptions.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This collection contains audio recordings that are currently only stored on cassette or reel-to-reel tapes. Researchers who wish to access these recordings may be required to pay for their digitization, and will be provided with access to the digitized version. Please contact the Public Services Coordinator and Outreach Librarian at speccoll@gwu.edu for additional information about this process.

did.unittitle: Rosemary Hills school integration oral history and documentation project

physdesc.extent: 7 full and 2 partial record center cartons, 1 document box, and 2 cassette tape boxes

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some interviews in this series are closed due to a lack of signed releases from the interviewees. Other interviewees signed releases but placed other restrictions on their interview's access or use. These restrictions are noted at the item-level.

The workflow of the project appears to be that participants were contacted and preliminarily interviewed by telephone, then a formal interview recorded on cassette tapes was conducted, a reel-to-reel "master" copy of the cassette tapes was made, the interview was transcribed, and finally the interview transcription was sent to the interviewee for approval along with a release form, which may or may not have been returned. Additional transcripts were created by archives staff in the early 2000s. Due to this process, recordings, contact files, and sometimes transcripts are included in the series for interviews whose participants either did not return releases or explicitly refused to sign releases.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Copies of some of the interviews in this series were obtained from or placed in other repositories of oral histories. Whenever this occurred, it is noted in the interviewee file.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is intellectually arranged with the oral histories first (arranged alphabetically by interviewee last name) and the documentary sources after. Physically, the materials for a single interview (e.g., cassette tapes, reel-to-reel tape, and transcript) are spread across multiple boxes because they are stored according to format. Transcripts and files for interviews that are currently closed have been moved to box R1, although the recordings continue to be stored alongside those for open interviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials generated in the 1970s through the efforts of Mary Jo Deering and others who embarked on a project to create a documentary teaching collection, including oral histories and printed sources, on school integration. The collection took as its primary topic the "Model School" controversy at Rosemary Hills elementary school. Participants in the Oral History Workshop at George Washington University, run by Mary Jo Deering, interviewed school administrators, teachers, parents, activists, and students about their experiences soon after the events surrounding this desegregation controversy.

The series consists of oral history recordings on reel-to-reel and cassette tapes, administrative and background files related to particular interviewees, interview transcripts, as well as publications, newspaper clippings, and other printed resources related to school desegregation. An item-level inventory of these printed materials exists in Box 16.

George Washington University oral histories

physdesc.extent: 7 full and 1 partial document boxes, 1 slim document box, 2 partial records center cartons, 4 partial tape boxes, and numerous digital recordings and transcription files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of oral history interviews related to the George Washington University conducted since 1974. Interviewees include university presidents, faculty, staff, administrators, and alumni.

Interviews were first conducted as part of the Oral History Program started by Mary Jo Deering in the 1970s. These include a series of eighteen interviews with Elmer Louis Kayser between 1975 and 1977. Kayser was University Historian at that time and was affiliated with the University as a student and faculty member from 1914 to his death in 1985.

In 1987, immediately prior to his retirement, GW President Lloyd Elliot gave a lengthy and broad-ranging series of oral history interviews that are included in this series. This series also includes a similar set of interviews conducted with President Stephen Joel Trachtenberg and his wife Francine Zorn Trachtenberg at the time of his retirement, however, the Trachtenbergs' interviews are not yet open to researchers.

In 1988, University Archivist G. David Anderson renewed efforts to document GW history through oral histories with faculty, staff and alumni. Other oral histories have also been conducted over the years by staff of Special Collections and by GW students. Under the direction of University Archivist Bergis Jules in 2013-2014, oral histories that expanded and diversified the picture of GW's history were pursued.

A separate series of oral histories conducted by the Medical Center Oral History Committee in the 1980s focused on faculty, staff, and alumni of that GW division. However, oral histories conducted with some of the same individuals by members of the library's oral history program also exist in this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is intellectually arranged alphabetically by interviewee last name, and chronologically thereunder when multiple interviews exist with the same person.

Physically, the materials for a single interview (e.g., cassette tapes, reel-to-reel tape, and transcript) are spread across multiple boxes because they are stored according to format. Transcripts and files for interviews that are currently closed have been moved to boxes whose numbers begin with an "R", although the recordings continue to be stored alongside those for open interviews.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some interviews in this series are closed due to a lack of signed releases from the interviewees (many releases from the Anderson era, in particular, could not be located). These restrictions are noted at the item-level.

did.unittitle: Don Balfour interviewed by David Anderson
Armecia J. Banks interviewed by Tasha Dorsey

bioghist.head: Biographical and Historical
bioghist.p: Armecia J. Banks was born October 9, 1954 in Washington, DC to Mable Banks. She has one son, Rodney I. Riley, Jr., of Washington, DC. Her first job was with Mackey Co. Ms. Banks received a high school degree at age 50, and began her career at GW in 1973 working in the dish room in Thurston Hall. She has worked at various food service locations, including Subway, Quiznos, and Starbucks. She is a member of Free Gospel Deliverance Temple, where she sings in the choir and serves as a greeter and member of the outreach team.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This oral history was conducted on April 11, 2014 by graduate student Tasha Dorsey. Ms. Dorsey conducted the oral history as part of a University Archives Diversity Research Fellowship awarded for the 2013-14 academic year.
The oral history discusses Armecia J. Bank's career working at GW in food services and her life experiences.

did.unittitle: Roderick S. French interviewed by Ashley Locke

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Roderick S. French served The George Washington University for twenty-eight years as a faculty member and administrator.

Dr. French earned an A.B. in philosophy from Kenyon College, an M.Div. in church history, theology and biblical studies from the Episcopal Theological School in Cambridge, Massachusetts, an S.T.M. in Modern church history from Union Theological Seminary in New York City, and a Ph.D. in American Civilization from The George Washington University. French began his career as the Executive Director of the Youth Department of the World Council of Churches in Geneva (1959-64). He later served as Special Assistant to the Director of the Office of Public Affairs of the Peace Corps from 1967 to 1968.

Dr. French joined The George Washington University as a Ph.D. student in 1968 and was appointed as the Associate Director of the University's Division of Experimental Programs in 1969. He was made director of the Division in 1979, and was responsible for university-wide curricular innovation and academic program development. In 1984 he was made Vice President for Academic Affairs, a position he held until 1995 when he stepped down to work with the University Honors Program. Dr. French left GW in 1997 to become the First Chancellor of the American University of Sharjah in the United Arab Emirates. Today, he is Chancellor Emeritus of the American University of Sharjah, a member of its Board of Trustees, and secretary of the Board of Directors of the AUS-USA Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This oral history interview was conducted on August 3, 12, and 17, 2011 by Assistant University Archivist, Ashley Locke. Total running time: 4 hours and 27 minutes. The interview includes the following subjects:

1) French's work for the World Council of Churches in Geneva. 2) French's work for the Peace Corps Headquarters 3) The socio-political atmosphere of Washington, D.C. and the country in the summer of 1968 4) George Washington University's campus culture in the late 1960s 5) GW President Lloyd Elliott 6) The Division of Experimental Programs 7) National Endowment for the Humanities Challenge Grant 8) Environmental Studies 9) Pedagogy at GW in the 1970s, educational reform and innovations 10)DEP Staff: Perry Wallace Sirulnik Seldman Lear Love Aron 11) The Free and Easy Society 12) The Dilthey Society 13) D.C. Community Humanities Council 14) National Trust for Historic Preservation 15) French's service as the Vice President for Academic Affairs 16) Council of Deans 17) Reorganization of School of International Affairs 18) Diversification of Student Body and Faculty, Educational Opportunities Program 19) Research 20) Enrollment Management 21) Radio and TV at GW 22) Naval ROTC unit at GW 23) Gelman Library 24) Middle States Accreditation 25) Continuing Education 26) Virginia Science and Technology Campus 27) GW Board of Trustees in the 1980s 28) The Center for Washington Area Studies 29) University seminar

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This oral history was conducted on April 11, 2014 by graduate student Tasha Dorsey. Ms. Dorsey conducted the oral history as part of a University Archives Diversity Research Fellowship awarded for the 2013-14 academic year.

bioghist.head: Biographical and Historical
bioghist.p: Douglas Johnson was born on August 3, 1955 in Clyo, Georgia to Bennit and Victoria Johnson. He is married to Bessie Louise Johnson, and has two children, Vicki Valorie Johnson and Douglas Johnson, Jr. He was educated at Effingham County High School in Springfield, Georgia and is a veteran of the Vietnam war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The oral history discusses Douglas Johnson's career working at GW in food services and his life experiences.

did.unittitle: Donald R. Lehman interviewed by Ashley Locke

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Donald R. Lehman (1940-) retired from The George Washington University on 31 December 2010 after serving more than thirty-eight years as a faculty member and administrator.

Dr. Lehman earned a BA in Physics from Rutgers University in 1962, an MS in Space Physics from the Air Force Institute of Technology in 1964, and a Ph.D. in Theoretical Physics from The George Washington University in 1970. Lehman joined the GW faculty as an Assistant Professor of Physics in 1972, becoming a fully Professor in 1982. He was made Chair of the Department of Physics in 1987, and he founded the Center for Nuclear Studies at the University in 1990.

From 1993 to 1996, Dr. Lehman held the position of Associate Vice President for Research and Graduate Studies. He was appointed Vice President for Academic Affairs in 1996, and served in this role until 2002 when he was made the George Gamow Professor of Theoretical Physics. He was the Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs from 2003 to 2010, and in 2010 he served as Senior Advisor to the President until his retirement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This oral history interview was conducted on May 3, 5, and 10, 2011 by Assistant University Archivist, Ashley Locke. Total running time: 3 hours and 35 minutes. The interview includes the following subjects:

-Dr. Lehman's experiences as a student and instructor at The George Washington University -President Stephen J. Trachtenberg -President Steven Knapp -GW's Center for Nuclear Studies -The Virginia Science and Technology Campus -The George Washington University's absorption of Mount Vernon College -The Washington Research Library Consortium -The Southeastern Universities Research Association -The University's Writing Program -The 2003 Strategic Plan for Academic Excellence -Tenure-promotion culture at GW -Columbian College of Arts and Sciences Dean Peg Barratt -Elliott School of International Affairs Dean Michael Brown -School of Business and Public Management Dean Susan Phillips -School of Business and Public Management Dean Doug Guthrie -Law School Dean Frederick M. Lawrence -Law School Dean Paul Schiff Berman -School of Engineering and Applied Science Dean David S. Dolling -Graduate School of Education and Human Development Dean Mary Hatwood Futrell -Graduate School of Education and Human Development Dean Michael J. Feuer -College of Professional Studies Dean Kathleen Burke. -School of Public Health and Health Services Dean Lynn Goldman -The creation of the College of Professional Studies. -The reorganization of the Graduate School of Education and Human Development in 2007 -The reorganization of the School of Engineering and Applied Science -Technology transfer -The creation of the University Roundtable -The George Washington Institute of Public Policy

physdesc.extent: 1 whole and 3 partial cassette tape boxes, and 2 document boxes

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some interviews in this series are closed due to a lack of signed releases from the interviewees. These restrictions are noted at the item-level.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred to the archives by Himmelfarb Health Sciences Library in 2003. Formerly ACC#1054

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is intellectually arranged alphabetically by interviewee last name, and chronologically thereunder when multiple interviews exist with the same person.

Physically, the materials for a single interview (e.g., cassette tapes, administrative file, and transcript) are spread across multiple boxes because they are stored according to format. Transcripts and files for interviews that are currently closed have been moved to boxes whose numbers begin with an "R", although the recordings continue to be stored alongside those for open interviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains records and oral history interviews from the Medical Center Oral History Project undertaken in the 1970s and 1980s. The interviews were done with faculty, staff and alumni of the GW Medical Center. Some of the individuals interviewed by this project were also interviewed by the university archives' oral history program, so may have interviews in both series.

did.unittitle: Foggy Bottom oral histories

physdesc.extent: 3 partial cassette tape boxes, 2 partial records center cartons, and digital recordings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is intellectually arranged alphabetically by interviewee last name, and chronologically thereunder when multiple interviews exist with the same person.
Physically, the materials for a single interview (e.g., cassette tapes, reel-to-reel tape, and transcript) are spread across multiple boxes because they are stored according to format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: GW has undertaken at least three distinct oral history projects with long-time residents of Foggy Bottom. The first was a small number of interviews done on behalf of the Oral History Program in the 1970s. Then, in the late 1990s, the university archives conducted a series of interviews as an outgrowth of a 1996 exhibit sponsored by the Foggy Bottom Association and the Gelman Library called "Fantastic Foggy Bottom: The Growth of a Community," which was designed in conjunction with GW's 175th Anniversary. Interviews from both of these efforts exist as cassette recordings, some reel-to-reel recordings, and transcripts.

In 2012, as part of the 100th anniversary of GW's presence in the Foggy Bottom neighborhood, another oral history project was conducted by GW Assistant Vice President for DC Relations Bernard Demczuk and GW graduate student Katherine Mead. These interviews exist solely as digital recordings.

This series also contains digital files of oral history recordings and transcripts created by undergraduate students in the GW history course HIST2020W, "Washington, DC: History, Culture, and Politics," taught by Dr. Christopher Klemek, who interviewed former and current residents of Foggy Bottom and Southwest neighborhoods.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous oral histories and administrative files

physdesc.extent: 1 partial document box, 3 partial cassette tape boxes, and 3 partial record center cartons

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Some interviews in this series are closed due to a lack of signed releases from the interviewees. These restrictions are noted at the item-level.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged intellectually by subject, with those subjects for which there are multiple interviews being listed first, and one-off interviews arranged alphabetically by interviewee name after that.
Physically, the materials for a single interview (e.g., cassette tapes, reel-to-reel tape, and transcript) are spread across multiple boxes because they are stored according to format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of oral histories and administrative files from the Oral History Program under Mary Jo Deering's direction which do not fit in other categories in this collection. These oral histories appear to have been done either as an exploration of a potential area for an oral history project, or as student projects. Major topics include fair housing programs and the performing arts in DC.
This series also contains interviews related to other collections in Special Collections, specifically interviews with Walter Fauntroy and Ari and Phyllis Kiev.

did.unittitle: Oral history program admininstrative files

scopecontent.p: Includes program reports, plans, and the finding aid for the original oral history collection.

did.unittitle: Housing: Morris Milgram interviewed by Mary Jo Deering

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Milgram's pioneering involvement in integrated housing, neighborhoods, and apartment complexes on the East Coast and especially in Montgomery County, Maryland. Also, the National Committee on Tithing in Investment and National Neighbors, an organization of integrated neighborhood associations. Fair housing laws.

did.unittitle: Housing: Joyce B. Siegel interviewed by Margaret Cutler

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Background of black community of Scotland in the Bethesda-Potomac area of Montgomery County, Maryland. Origins and progress of plans to upgrade housing conditions and create community organizations capable of controlling local decisions.

scopecontent.p: Documents apparently gathered in preparation for interviewing Milgram and Siegel about housing discrimination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reminiscences of the then-National Treasurer Emeritus of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP); civil rights activities and political activities as a Socialist

did.unittitle: M. Denis de Rougemont interviewed by Mary Jo Deering

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Oral history interview in French with M. Denis de Rougemont Swiss author, Director of the Centre europeen de la Culture, Geneva, Switzerland. Topics include origins of various European activist groups in the 1930s, and during and after WWII; Congress of Motreaux (1947) and the Haugh (1948); creation of the European Cultural Center; Winston Churchill and the European movement.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Interview is closed due to lack of a release form.
